newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian regulator wants uniform gas laws.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian regulator wants uniform gas laws.

text.p: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) said on Monday it wanted to see uniform national gas pipeline regulations including a single regulatory body for the industry.

"The ACCC believes that high transaction costs, economic inefficiencies and regulatory uncertainty in multiple access regimes, makes an overwhelming case for a uniform national pipeline access regulatory framework," ACCC deputy chairman Allan Asher said in a speech to the Australian Gas Association convention.
Asher also said the Federal Government gas industry reform task force should consider tightening up the code on future price regulation.
"The commission believes that the performance of the regulator will suffer if price regulation becomes a mechanism for implicitly implementing other government (gas) policies."

Asher said the draft code needed modification, particularly in relation to future gas processing, and the ACCC wanted to see a study of the economics of gas processing in South Australia's Cooper Basin and offshore Victorian Gippsland Basin.

"The commission is particularly concerned that an absence of effective access to the Moomba facility (which treats Cooper and Eromanga Basin gas in Queensland) may reduce the number of potential new entrants," Asher said.

In a later speech to the convention, Queensland mines and energy minister Tom Gilmore said his state government also had concerns about the current draft code on pipeline access and distribution systems.
A national code in its present form could not operate in Queensland without seriously disupting access arrangements already in place, Gilmore said.
"We are particularly keen to develop, through the code, arrangements which recognise tariff structures set through a competitive bidding process," Gilmore said.
